articles.headline: As Homeowners’ Dreams Die, He’s the Undertaker
articles.snippet: When a resident won’t leave a foreclosed house, a real estate agent comes knocking to persuade them to leave.
articles.abstract: When a resident won’t leave a foreclosed house, a real estate agent comes knocking to persuade them to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE VILLA, Ill. — If you see Joseph Laubinger on your doorstep, start packing. His courtly presence means you have exhausted all excuses, arguments and options for keeping your house.

articles.headline: In Washington, a Renewed Taste for Auto Safety
articles.snippet: A crisis for Toyota has become a catalyst for regulatory change with support from the White House, both political parties and the industry.
articles.abstract: A crisis for Toyota has become a catalyst for regulatory change with support from the White House, both political parties and the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the new world of auto regulation, cars could be required to have “black boxes” to record crash data and be able to stop even with the engine at full power. Automakers could be ordered to recall defective vehicles immediately and pay safety fees to cover the costs of federal oversight.

articles.headline: Market Drop Fueled by a Crisis, Anxiety and an Error
articles.snippet: The market’s wild ride Thursday suggests that investors are again growing more hesitant to own assets like stocks and bonds.
articles.abstract: The market’s wild ride Thursday suggests that investors are again growing more hesitant to own assets like stocks and bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Combine one part nervous traders, one part Greek crisis and one part trader error. Stir in one part central bank complacency. Bring to boil. Panic.

articles.headline: European Bank’s Assurances Fail to Placate Investors
articles.snippet: The European Central Bank disappointed investors hoping for decisive action to contain the euro zone’s increasingly virulent debt crisis, pushing the euro to another low.
articles.abstract: The European Central Bank disappointed investors hoping for decisive action to contain the euro zone’s increasingly virulent debt crisis, pushing the euro to another low.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank disappointed investors hoping for decisive action on Thursday to contain the euro zone’s increasingly virulent debt crisis, pushing the euro to another low for the year.

articles.headline: Pakistani Taliban Are Said to Expand Alliances
articles.snippet: The group that investigators suspect in the Times Square bomb plot has combined forces with other militants to extend its reach and ambitions.
articles.abstract: The group that investigators suspect in the Times Square bomb plot has combined forces with other militants to extend its reach and ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban, which American investigators suspect were behind the attempt to bomb Times Square, have in recent years combined forces with Al Qaeda and other groups, threatening to extend their reach and ambitions, Western diplomats, intelligence officials and experts say.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: China’s Energy Use Threatens Goals on Warming
articles.snippet: China’s consumption of oil and coal-generated electricity each jumped 24 percent in the first quarter.
articles.abstract: China’s consumption of oil and coal-generated electricity each jumped 24 percent in the first quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Even as China has set ambitious goals for itself in clean-energy production and reduction of global warming gases, the country’s surging demand for power from oil and coal has led to the largest six-month increase in the tonnage of human generated greenhouse gases ever by a single country.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Said to Dismiss Goldman
articles.snippet: The American International Group is turning to Citigroup and Bank of America to replace Goldman Sachs as the main corporate adviser as the insurer reorganizes.
articles.abstract: The American International Group is turning to Citigroup and Bank of America to replace Goldman Sachs as the main corporate adviser as the insurer reorganizes.
articles.lead_paragraph: As its legal troubles mount, Goldman Sachs is losing a big corporate client: the American International Group.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Senate Nod to Fed Audit Is Expected
articles.snippet: By a vote of 61 to 33, the Senate decided not to force big banks to shrink. An amendment for a one-time audit of the Fed is expected to pass next week.
articles.abstract: By a vote of 61 to 33, the Senate decided not to force big banks to shrink. An amendment for a one-time audit of the Fed is expected to pass next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday rejected an effort by liberal Democrats to break up some of the biggest banks, defeating an amendment to financial regulatory legislation that would have imposed new limits on the size and scope of financial companies.

articles.headline:
Volatile Week
on Wall Street Ends With Another Slide
articles.snippet: Brushing off a strong U.S. jobs report, traders focused on lingering questions about European debt and Thursday’s plunge.
articles.abstract: Brushing off a strong U.S. jobs report, traders focused on lingering questions about European debt and Thursday’s plunge.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was The Day After on Wall Street — the uneasy end to a hair-raising week that, for a few terrifying moments, left the financial world stunned.

articles.headline: British Parties Jockey to Form Governing Alliance
articles.snippet: David Cameron, the Conservative leader, reached out to the Liberal Democrats as Prime Minister Gordon Brown signaled that he would not immediately step down.
articles.abstract: David Cameron, the Conservative leader, reached out to the Liberal Democrats as Prime Minister Gordon Brown signaled that he would not immediately step down.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats began intensive talks on Friday to try to fashion an unlikely marriage that would allow them to form a government quickly and reassure jittery financial markets after an election that denied any party a clear majority.

articles.headline:
Economy Gains
Impetus as U.S.
Adds 290,000 Jobs
articles.snippet: Payrolls surged with an unexpectedly strong 290,000 jobs last month, but the unemployment rate rose to 9.9 percent.
articles.abstract: Payrolls surged with an unexpectedly strong 290,000 jobs last month, but the unemployment rate rose to 9.9 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite growing unease in the financial markets, the American economy is gathering steam, adding an unexpectedly large number of jobs last month.

articles.headline: Europeans Move to Head Off Spread of Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Leaders from the euro-area countries promised steps to stanch a debt crisis before markets open on Monday.
articles.abstract: Leaders from the euro-area countries promised steps to stanch a debt crisis before markets open on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Leaders from the euro zone countries signed off on a support package for Greece on Friday night and pledged to take steps to stanch a spreading debt crisis before markets opened on Monday morning.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Judy Dempsey
